Ohio Proposal Would Award Electoral Votes to Popular Vote Winner
column8:
I don't quite follow. What "individual responsibility" do you think I'm neglecting?
Moreover, I'm not questioning the legality of the Electoral College or the legitamacy of it's outcome. But it's definitely the case that the Electoral College weights some American votes more heavily that other American votes based on geography...and by extension, party. Maybe you have a reason you tell yourself why citizen votes shouldn't count equally- as they might in a more popular based counting system- but I'm skeptical if the answer isn't some variant of "the GOP deserves special help."

column1: Ohio Proposal Would Award Electoral Votes to Popular Vote Winner
column8:
"But it is true that the Electoral College only "protects" some voters by weighting their votes over others. I'm sure you've noticed that Presidential candidates really only campaign in a handful of states."
This is sophistry. The idea that the EC unfairly advantages smaller states over bigger ones is ludicrous, and unsupported by the facts. California has 55 electoral votes; Wyoming, Montana and a few other states each have three. Are you seriously suggesting that their feeble, little, paltry three EC votes give those small states an advantage over CA? Please.
Whichever Democrat is running for president already has an automatic 20% head start on the way to 270 because that Democrat can count on CA without even breaking a sweat there; all they do in CA is raise money.
Contrary to your assertions, the EC ensures that presidential candidates campaign in more states than they otherwise would; without it, 17 or 18 urban areas would decide the outcome of our national elections, and no candidate would ever waste any time or money visiting any of the states that don't have those cities.
You have neither logic nor facts on your side here.

column1: Ohio Proposal Would Award Electoral Votes to Popular Vote Winner
column8:
David, the EC does the opposite - it makes swaths of American votes matter, not meaningless. California conservatives are so outnumbered there that their voices are drowned out regardless of whether or not the EC exists; junking it so that the voices of voters in Wyoming, Idaho, the Dakotas, West Virginia, and Montana, et al, are marginalized makes no sense - unless you're a leftist who wants the leftist bias of the urban areas to dominate America.
If the EC didn't exist, then the 17 or 18 most populous urban areas in the country would decide all of our national elections, and nobody else would matter.
The EC ensures that the politicians consider the voices and views of those in less-densely populated areas. It was an absolute stroke of brilliance on the part of the Founders, who were terrified of the idea of a pure democracy.
